text: I think i might have to stop exercising outside. The covid cases are off the charts here in the UK.

elements.text: I think i might have to stop exercising outside. The covid cases are off the charts here in the UK.

text: That’s really tough. I think spending time outside has been one of main things keeping me sane through all this. Stay safe!

elements.text: That’s really tough. I think spending time outside has been one of main things keeping me sane through all this. Stay safe!

text: my impression is that outdoor activity at a respectable distance (the six foot rec) is not a risk

elements.text: my impression is that outdoor activity at a respectable distance (the six foot rec) is not a risk

text: I have been running outdoors in NYC regularly throughout the pandemic

elements.text: I have been running outdoors in NYC regularly throughout the pandemic

text:
Yeah in general it isn't.
I have been riding daily with a mask.
But this new strain in the UK has me extra worried.
Random survey now says 1 in 50 people in the UK have Covid .
My wife is in one of the extremely vulnerable categories.

elements.text:
Yeah in general it isn't.
I have been riding daily with a mask.
But this new strain in the UK has me extra worried.
Random survey now says 1 in 50 people in the UK have Covid .
My wife is in one of the extremely vulnerable categories.

text:
Other thing about the UK is we are basically out of hospital beds. (or more accurately there are loads of beds (they build a ton in March) but no staff due to sickness).

So like idk if I get hit by a car or something.

elements.text:
Other thing about the UK is we are basically out of hospital beds. (or more accurately there are loads of beds (they build a ton in March) but no staff due to sickness).

So like idk if I get hit by a car or something.

text:
Really though, I think it is probably me subconsciously trying to exert control (or the illusion of it) on my environment.

I can't do anything about the thousands of people getting covid.
But I can stay in my house.

Probably the effect is nothing, after all I still get deliveries, which are probably more dangerous than cycling.

text: The rate here in London is reportedly one in 30 people

text: 7-day rates of new cases in London.  it's rather frustrating how ineffective the second lockdown (November 5th - December 2nd) has been.  only now there are small hints that the infection is slowing down

text: I am interested in this as well. I've tried running, but have no idea if running in a place where a maskless covid person was 2-5 minutes ago could pose a risk. Would you know anything <@U8JP5B9T2>?

elements.text: I am interested in this as well. I've tried running, but have no idea if running in a place where a maskless covid person was 2-5 minutes ago could pose a risk. Would you know anything

text:
<@U6QGE7S86> For respiratory pathogens, we think of 3 modes of transmission:

1. Aerosol: very fine water mist, can stay suspended in air for long time
2. Droplet - larger drops of water (still very small) that typically fall to the ground within seconds
3. Fomites - droplets that have landed on surfaces and are transferred to mucous membranes via touching contaminated surfaces then touching your face.
All of these routes have been described for SARS-CoV2, but #2 is far and away the most prevalent.

elements.text: For respiratory pathogens, we think of 3 modes of transmission:
Aerosol: very fine water mist, can stay suspended in air for long time
Droplet - larger drops of water (still very small) that typically fall to the ground within seconds
Fomites - droplets that have landed on surfaces and are transferred to mucous membranes via touching contaminated surfaces then touching your face.
All of these routes have been described for SARS-CoV2, but #2 is far and away the most prevalent.

text: So yes, in principle, there could be a cloud of exhalation with some aerosol from a maskless runner, but it's very unlikely. If you were running for a couple of minutes directly behind someone, that's a different story

elements.text: So yes, in principle, there could be a cloud of exhalation with some aerosol from a maskless runner, but it's very unlikely. If you were running for a couple of minutes directly behind someone, that's a different story

text: Thanks a lot. We're lucky to have you answering stuff like that here. Thanks.
